pros: There are some wonderful people that work there!
cons: A dedicated employee for 10+ years. Pay very low. Do not trust the admin team. While admin gets raises per year, it is rare for staff to get raises. Review the Nonprofit Explorer - Form 990 to see how much the top 10 earn at SMU. Compare year to year and see how much some of the salaries have increased annually.

pros: Beautiful campus, some of the good, committed staff despite the ongoing organizational challenges
cons: Frequent leadership changes, lack of infrastructure, location challenges

pros:
- I truly loved my colleagues and manager (they deserved so much better!). Encountered many caring people during my time there.
- Since it's a Catholic school, there are lots of paid holidays off and good sick time accrual (although comparably less vacation days)
cons:
Like a lot of smaller, less-prestigious schools, SMUMN has been hit hard by the pandemic -- especially the Winona campus, which the school still insists on investing a lot more money into at the expense of the Twin Cities campus. However, Winona's been losing money/enrollment for many years, and administration's approach was to keep doing the same things and wonder why they weren't working, while getting increasingly more desperate. As others have mentioned, I think this is really catching up to them right now, and I honestly can't see a sustainable future for SMUMN if things keep going as they have been.

Many of the adult students in Minneapolis are attracted by the comparably lower tuition, but then are faced with minimal support -- overworked adjuncts and student services, no spare laptops, no mental health services, expensive textbooks (a problem everywhere, but the bookstore is run by Barnes & Noble, which exacerbates the issue here). The admin constantly changes up the approach, tanking programs after a year or two without doing evidence-based assessments of WHY programs weren't attracting students. Overall, the program development and "strategy" can feel borderline predatory, very oriented toward a vague sense of the market while not being backed by real research or needs assessment.

Administration doesn't particularly respect or support the majority of people on the campus, especially admin/support staff, adjunct faculty (the bulk of faculty in Minneapolis), etc. As others have mentioned, there's lot of back-patting among the admin, betrayed by low morale, regular turnover, and much lower pay than average.

The pension is only vested if you work there for 5+ years, so I imagine they don't wind up having to pay it out for most people!

I appreciated the Lasallian values when I started, but it's clear that the administration doesn't really live those out in practice. The administration is conservative and fearful of change, especially when it comes to true inclusivity and diversity (vs. outdated lip service). While living through both the pandemic and the uprising in Minneapolis (and the world!), it was really disappointing to see the administration doubling down on backwards and outdated ideologies. It's 2022, and their approach is incredibly alienating for a ton of students and staff. Hiring a diversity & inclusion specialist (years too late!) doesn't mitigate the larger structural issues.

Campus buildings in Minneapolis are outdated, not accessibility-friendly, and have terrible WiFi (which made it extra challenging for students to come to campus to study).

Public health measures dwindled after the early days of the pandemic. There was a push to get back to campus for optics' sake without a real interrogation of why that was needed and why it might have been better for morale to support WFH options -- especially since SMUMN, with so many adult and online students, might have been well-positioned to innovate in this area. Again, it just felt backwards.

job_title: Coordinator of Academic Administration in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Wonderful community, amazing colleagues, the organization is seeking to be more inclusive. The mission of the school is to make education affordable and accessible to all, which is something to stand behind. These are the kind of people you'll want to know for the rest of your life and will be sad to leave.
cons: The compensation is not market competitive, there is little room for upward growth, the culture is heavily rooted in patriarchal ideology, and delegation of resources/tasks needs a lot of work, and turnover is high (ie. most people are over-worked and under-paid.)  Tuition remission requires a contract upon completion of the degree, which means in order to actually get your degree paid for by the organization, you have to sign over 3 to 7 years of your life while making pennies.  It's difficult to even afford to pay rent in this city on the salaries offered for program coordinators.

review_title: Low Pay, Least Diversity/Transparency, Lack of Career Development Opprotunities
pros: The New Leadership. The Former President William Mann is not out, and the university has new leadership including new President, Provost, and many administrators.
cons:
No opportunity for growth and that is one of the reasons I am about to leaving. The pay was really low [no pay increase in next few years] and if you had ambitions to grow in your role, you quickly learned that that was not the place for you.

Pressure is super high, but reward is super low. 

They say the importance of diversity, but no diverse culture at all. You will quickly learn this in a few weeks. Many are leaving. Women and minorities (race/ethnicity/sexual orientation)... don't even imagine yourself working here. 

The bottom of pay line. 

Worst place for faculty -- too many workloads (you are being asked to engage in many many many obligations beyond your contract; that does not mean you would get paid more)

The dept chair's job: only $ 1,000 stipend plus your salary 

Many faculty members receiving welfare from the govt. 

People are nice overall; but there are some "good old boys" mentality among people in leadership. They would not write a good letter of recommendation for you (esp. when you want to leave for a better job opportunity/career development) even though you do your job alright -- because they want to keep you here!

pros: There are wonderful staff and faculty members, and students who are achieving wonderful things. The Lasallian intellectual heritage is worthwhile and worth preserving.
cons: The tradition of drawing top executives from the dwindling FSC (exclusively male, Catholic, and celibate) results in the institution being out of touch by design. The administration is incompetent (and not genuinely respected), particularly in the area of identifying and addressing basic needs that they don't perceive as bringing lots of extra prestige or revenue to the University. My supervisor and the HR department repeatedly failed to follow their own policies or fulfill their basic obligations to me as an employee and constantly moved the goalposts for my job performance. Some colleagues seemed to just simply disappear; turnover is high.

pros: I love the people here, I love the mission of the university and I really believe in it. Benefits are great compared to other places I've been! Paid maternity leave is a huge plus for me.
cons:
People do not handle change well here, and they really need to embrace healthy growth as an organization. There are many leadership problems as well. Trust issues on both sides. I often feel very caught in the middle. 

Salary really really sucks.

review_title: does not uphold its own Lasallian Catholic mission and identity
pros: There is nothing positive here.
cons: The University should be ashamed of itself regarding the treatment of an employee who has served the university for more than 50 years. This person was terminated, had his keys taken away, and was escorted from the building because his supervisor had it in for him.  The people involved in the handling of this situation all behaved disgracefully. There is no sense of family or community here anymore.
